title: How to Make a Canteen Yard Sale

steps.headline: Write a list of foods and drinks you are going to buy/make.
steps.description:
A list may go something like this:
Jug of cloudy lemonade
Jug of squash
Pot of tea
Pot of coffee
Assorted chocolate bars
Sandwiches of various fillings
Fruit

steps.headline: Buy any dry, long lasting ingredients, like flour, sugar etcetera.
Find a place you can sell your food and beverages.
steps.description: For example, if you live on a busy street, do it on your front yard. But if you live on a quiet street, see if you can do it on a friends front yard.

steps.headline: Write up a list of prices for things.
steps.description:
For example:
1 cup of coffee, tea or cocoa = £0.90
1 sandwich = £1.45 And so on

steps.headline: Make up any cakes, biscuits and things like that.
steps.description: On wikiHow, there are plenty of cake recipes!

steps.headline: Make up a large, colourful sign, saying 'CANTEEN YARD SALE.
Make up some leaflets listing foods and drinks you will be selling, and from what times, and your address.
Post the leaflets through local doors, and if possible, put a few up around town.
Make up a large piece of paper, with cake and biscuit names, and the ingredients listed on it (just in case anyone is allergic).
Find a container to keep money in, and make up the following change:
steps.description: £1/$1 worth of pennies/cents. £10/$10 worth of £1/$1 coins. A handful of five, ten, twenty and fifty pence/cent coins. 3 £10/$10 notes. 5 £5/$5 notes.

methods.name: The morning of the canteen sale

steps.headline: Make up any sandwiches, drinks et cetera.
Set up your table with sheets of paper, food, drinks, price lists, cups, mugs et cetera.
Sweep your yard so it is clean.
Keep your money with you at all times.
If anyone asks you anything, be polite and courteous.
Consider anything that went wrong.
steps.description: For example, if a particular type of drink didn't sell well, next time put it as one cup free with something that sold well.

steps.headline: Count your money, and see if you made profit.
steps.description: If you didn't, next time rise the prices a little, or put up less variety.

text:
3 weeks before Write a list of foods and drinks you are going to buy/make. A list may go something like this:
Jug of cloudy lemonade
Jug of squash
Pot of tea
Pot of coffee
Assorted chocolate bars
Sandwiches of various fillings
Fruit Buy any dry, long lasting ingredients, like flour, sugar etcetera.  1 week before Find a place you can sell your food and beverages. For example, if you live on a busy street, do it on your front yard. But if you live on a quiet street, see if you can do it on a friends front yard. Write up a list of prices for things. For example:
1 cup of coffee, tea or cocoa = £0.90
1 sandwich = £1.45 And so on The day before Make up any cakes, biscuits and things like that. On wikiHow, there are plenty of cake recipes! Make up a large, colourful sign, saying 'CANTEEN YARD SALE. CHEAP FOODS AND DRINKS AVAILABLE!' Make up some leaflets listing foods and drinks you will be selling, and from what times, and your address.  Post the leaflets through local doors, and if possible, put a few up around town.  Make up a large piece of paper, with cake and biscuit names, and the ingredients listed on it (just in case anyone is allergic).  Find a container to keep money in, and make up the following change: £1/$1 worth of pennies/cents. £10/$10 worth of £1/$1 coins. A handful of five, ten, twenty and fifty pence/cent coins. 3 £10/$10 notes. 5 £5/$5 notes. The morning of the canteen sale Make up any sandwiches, drinks et cetera.  Put up your colourful sign.  Set up your table with sheets of paper, food, drinks, price lists, cups, mugs et cetera.  Sweep your yard so it is clean.  During the sale Keep your money with you at all times.  If anyone asks you anything, be polite and courteous.  After the sale Consider anything that went wrong. For example, if a particular type of drink didn't sell well, next time put it as one cup free with something that sold well. Count your money, and see if you made profit. If you didn't, next time rise the prices a little, or put up less variety.
